resources.string: Welcome! We are going to take a quick view at the UI components that make up Android apps.

-Android is an open-source operating system that is based in Linux\n-Though the open-source nature of Android, the most widely used version is maintained by Google\n-It is the most widely used mobile operating system
-Java was the original language used\n-Kotlin is now the preferred language by Google, however Java is still used
-All major updates are named after desserts and in alphabetical order\n-This version\'s name is Tiramisu!
-XML stands for extensible markup language\n-Used for storing data
How is it used in Android?

-Used to create content on Android Activities
-Stores information such as color, strings, and images to be called
-Best practice is to save all editable information into its own XML file within the resources
-Each resource has its own name and description
-We are in one right now!\n-Refers to the screen layouts (pages)\n-We will move on to the next screen to dive into Activities a bit more
How do we tell activities what to do?

-Each XML file can be associated with a class
-Instead of a Main function, there is the onCreate function
-When an activity loads or changes, the onCreaate is called
-Listeners can be placed here or outside if the task is more specific
-Listeners tell components within activities what they do when interacted with\n-Buttons, switches, spinners can all get listeners
-Contains important information about the application contents\n-Sets a range of information from labels at the top of the screen to the target API\n-Without the Manifest, your app will not function
